results.title: Melbourne
results.creator_credit: Douglas White, Eric Thompson and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life in Australia”.
This film, directed by Douglas White, opens to the roar of a crowd at the MCG. The camera then sweeps across the city of Melbourne as the soundtrack fades to an easy listening score by composer George Dreyfus (notable for his TV score works like the classic theme from Rush). The film has no commentary, just a skeleton narrative, which is ingeniously used to feature the city of Melbourne. We see a young man wave goodbye to his mum and drive past the commission flats to pick up his girlfriend (Meg from “Prisoner” - the young Elspeth Ballantyne). In the city, people work and shop and the music turns more dramatic as the crowds and traffic grow. In the evening the couple window shop for funky furniture and see “Busybody” at Her Majesty’s, then twist the light fantastic at a bar. Part of the Life in Australia series, produced by The Australian Commonwealth Film Unit.

results.title: The Lord Mayor
results.creator_credit: Chris McGill, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Who is at the centre of the administration of a big city? With this film the viewer spends a day in the company of the Lord Mayor of Sydney, Alderman Sir Nicholas Shehadie, OBE. Narrated by John Laws.

results.title: The Living north
results.creator_credit: Neil Howe, Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Surveys the potential of the Northern Territory, depicting its industries such as mining, fisheries, beef cattle and pearling and studying developments in transport, education and housing.

results.title: Lifeline to Adelaide
results.creator_credit: John Kingsford-Smith and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Adelaide’s water supply is boosted by the 50 miles of piping from Mannum on the Murray. With the lowest rainfall of any Australian capital, heavy industry expanding each year, and a rapid increase in homes and population, the six reservoirs in the Lofty Ranges are unable to supply enough water for Adelaide’s needs. An extra supply of water is pumped through 72 inch concrete pipes to dams near the city.

results.title: Launceston
results.creator_credit: John Edwards, Peter Young, Eric Thompson and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life in Australia”.
Aspects of life in Launceston. Industries include Paton and Baldwins woollen mills, Repco ball bearing factory, timber mills and furniture manufacturers. Shows schools, the general hospital, churches, and the historic home of Entally built in 1820. Motor racing at Longford, bicycyle racing, water skiing and archery are popular forms of recreation. Theatres, restaurants and night clubs, provide a variety of evening entertainment.

results.title: The Konrads: swim champions
results.creator_credit: Jack S. Allan and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Indicates the swimming and training methods of John and Ilsa Konrads and other swimmers of the 1950s as well as some from the past such as “Boy” Charlton and Bonnie Mealing.

results.title: Keep it green
results.creator_credit: Antonio Colacino, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: One-third of the world’s agricultural production is destroyed each year by pests and diseases. Geographical isolation has helped protect Australia so far, but with increasing frequency and speed of modern communication the risk of their accidental introduction becomes greater every year. Plant Quarantine Inspectors check cargoes and passengers’ baggage, as they come into the country. Within industries such as sugar and rice, scientists work to improve commercial varieties and reduce disease.

results.title: It needn't happen
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board and Tasmanian Government Film Unit
results.brief_description: Warns against accidents to small children in the home through the example of a little girl, the accidents that might have happened and how they could be prevented. Boiling water, medicine and sharp objects left within reach of the child, and over-boisterous games are all potentially dangerous.
